title: 103_hr3060
content: The Act may be cited as the "Electronic Funds Transfer Federal Salary Act" and aims to ensure safe, economical, and effective payroll administration. The "Electronic Funds Transfer Federal Salary Act" amends Section 3332 of title 31, United States Code, to define financial organization and authorize the Secretary of the Treasury to require electronic transfers for employee pay if deemed practical and in the interest of economy or effectiveness. The "Electronic Funds Transfer Federal Salary Act" allows the Secretary of the Treasury to mandate electronic funds transfer for employee pay if practical and beneficial. Employees must designate a financial organization to receive payments, and agency heads must report this information to the Secretary. The Secretary may not charge any financial organization fees for payments made under this section, and financial organizations cannot charge employees for handling payments authorized by the Secretary. Employees with annual pay below $20,000 can request exemption from electronic funds transfer. The Secretary may exempt employees with annual pay below $20,000 from electronic funds transfer requirements. National security exceptions apply, including exemptions for the Central Intelligence Agency and its employees. The Central Intelligence Agency and its employees may be exempt from regulations and requirements to protect intelligence sources and methods. Acceptance of payment by a financial organization from the United States constitutes full acquittance. Payments to individuals can be made through electronic fund transfers authorized by the Secretary upon request. The United States can make payments to individuals through electronic fund transfers authorized by the Secretary upon request. Amendments to title 31, United States Code, include technical and conforming changes.
